newsitem.title: UK: Base metals gearing up for rally - broker Wolff.
newsitem.headline: Base metals gearing up for rally - broker Wolff.

text.p: Base metals prices seem to be gathering steam for another rally like the one seen from 1993 to 1995, when prices gained 102 percent on average, broker Rudolf Wolff said.
"The same scenario now looks set to unfold again," analyst William Adams said in a report.

"With base metal stocks for most of the metals approaching critically low levels, or in the case of lead and copper below critical levels, a combination of supply deficits and stronger demand should underpin firmer metal prices," he said.

World economic growth is expected to grow at 4.00 percent next year, which would be the highest since 1988, with low inflation and interest rates providing a strong incentive for economies to expand, Adams said.

"Many of the metals are facing a supply/demand deficit in 1997 and 1998, and considering the trade have been destocking in 1996, an improvement in the order flow of semi-fabricated products should be quickly reflected in higher demand for metal," the report said.
In addition, if fund managers believe the upside potential in stocks and bonds is limited, they may reallocate resources into commodities, Adams added.
But some metals will do better than others.
Copper prices will lag, just as zinc did in 1993-1995, since the relatively high copper price over the past several years stimulated investment in new projects, keeping the market well supplied.
"That said, there is some uncertainty over Chinese requirements and copper could still remain a bull market if China restocks heavily," the report said.
Copper stocks are expected to rise above critical levels in 1997, but not by a large margin.
Tin, lead and zinc stocks are expected to fall below important levels in 1997, while aluminium's and nickel's stocks are forecast to drop, but not below key levels.
